overview_of_class: E. pluribus unum. "Out of many, one." This course will study the way in which American society is divided into various subgroups and subcultures. The bases of differentiation range from racial and ethnic groups , to religion, sexuality, to lifestyle and interest groups of all kinds, and regional and urban/rural subcultures. . The focus will be on how groups develop subcultures with distinct norms and symbols, create internal organizations and group solidarity, how they define boundaries between in group and out group, how they relate in conflict /competition or cooperation/tolerance with other groups. Consequences of these subcultures for individual identity, and for social inequality in terms of economic outcomes and politics and power. Students will engage in readings and discussions of these issues and through a focused case study of a specific subculture of choice. Grades based on reading response, participation, presentation, and final paper.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
During preregistration this course is only open to Sociology Majors & Minors.

This course is open to all undergraduates during regular registration.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By the end of the course students will have a a theoretical understanding of subcultures, the ability to apply theories critically in an empirical research study of subcultures, and the ability to present ideas orally and in writing.

Grades will be based on reading responses, participation, class presentation, and a final paper.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Minimal short lectures, student presentations, and discussion of readings.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Reading response and participation 20%, presentations 30%, final paper 50%.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: All materials for this course will be made available on Canvas - no purchase necessary.
